column16: Ballot Comment

Not clear if/how provenance is represented in this FHIR Implementation Guide.  Provenance (who, what, when, where, why) is essential at:  1) point of origination (at the source, for newly captured content), 2) point of update (for newly updated content, preserving previous content and its provenance).

Who = subject of care/information (typically the patient)
Who = performer of action taken
Who = author of information captured or updated
Who = organization
What = action taken
When = date/time of action taken
When = date/time of information capture or update
Where = physical location of action taken
Where = physical location of information capture or update
Where = network address and/or device ID where information captured or updated
Why = rationale, purpose of action taken
Why = rationale, purpose of information capture or update

Granularity of provenance (e.g., binding authorship to content) may be at the dataset or element level.

Is this a FHIR Implementation Guide or is it a FHIR Profile?  Please make description consistent.

The QICoreEncounterDiet value set (http://hl7.org/fhir/us/qicore/2019SEP/ValueSet-qicore-encounter-diet.html) contains many diets that are not evidence based or considered appropriate by the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics.
Under the link “Encounter – Diet” (http://hl7.org/fhir/us/qicore/2019SEP/ValueSet-qicore-encounter-diet.html); there are diets that are no longer considered appropriate or evidence-based.

The list of diets included in the QICoreEncounterDiet value set contains diets that are no longer considered appropriate or evidence based by the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics. The list should be reviewed and updated accordingly.

column14: This initiative began in 2013 with the creation of the Quality Improvement Domain Analysis Model (QIDAM), which drew on the vMR and QDM as sources of requirements. QIDAM gave rise to the QUICK logical model in 2014. Originally, QUICK was entirely independent of FHIR. However, recognizing the broader community focus on FHIR, QUICK was aligned, structurally and semantically, as closely as possible to FHIR. This alignment not only creates a common model for quality and interoperability, but will also make it easier in the future to leverage other FHIR-related efforts, such as Clinical Document Architecture (CDA) on FHIR. The conceptual, logical, and physical models in this initiative are, respectively, QIDAM, QUICK, and the QI-Core FHIR Profiles.
column16:
This statement is not entirely accurate. The original QUICK model did derive from QIDAM and was relatively independent of FHIR. However, the model was not subsequently aligned to FHIR. Rather, a set of QI Core profiles were developed directly on FHIR and the QUICK model instead became the logical view derived from the corresponding FHIR profiles. This is an important difference, which is important to remember as we are now discussing the QUICK logical model as a model that would derive from the QDM and QIDAM, a model closely aligned to FHIR, from which QI Core profiles would be derived. The directionality of the derivation is important especially for upcoming modeling discussions.

Note that later in the document, the authors state that: "Using FHIR to define the QUICK logical model seems to reverse the usual flow from conceptual model to logical model to physical model. This is true, and has been the source of some controversy. Without revisiting that debate, the bottom line is whether the QUICK model has the right set of objects and attributes that are needed for quality improvement applications. To assure that QUICK does meet those requirements, the QI-Core profiles were created. QI-Core fills any gaps such as missing attributes and unspecified value sets that might make QUICK insufficient for quality improvement applications. In turn, QUICK is derived from QI-Core profiles, rather than directly from FHIR, providing an author-focused view of the FHIR resources profiled by QI-Core."

column14: It is expected that QI-Core will evolve over time to include some of the extensional content when the community identifies a common need and the additional content has been validated.
column16: Technically, as the logical model evolves over time to represent new requirements and use cases and to reflect changes to the QDM model, QI Core IGs for all final release versions of FHIR should be provided as different systems may support different versions of FHIR (for instance, we are still on FHIR DSTU2) and later versions of the QDM may result in  QI Core profiles for a specific version of FHIR that are different from previously released QI Core profiles for that version of FHIR.

AllergyIntolerance is very closely related to Condition in both structure and semantics. Rather than introduce an attribute called resolutionAge, it should simply support abatement[x] as this will ensure better consistency between both resources.
column17: AllergyIntolerance should have abatement, not resolutionAge

column16: BodyStructure is a problematic resource given its strong overlap with Condition (in particular, if one considers the morphology attribute). CIMI has requested that FHIR abandon the BodyStructure resource in favor of using Condition and introducing a BodySite data type which can be referenced from BodyStructure.

CareTeam.member should have a cardinality of 0..1. It is often the case that a care team specifies a role but does not specify a member for that role or the member that will perform the role may not be known at the time. Please note the cardinality changes proposed for R5 by LHS.
Recommend discussing with Patient Care making dueTo and occurredFollowing first class attributes of Condition.
column17: Recommend dueTo and occurredFollowing for base Condition resource

column16: Recommend adding doNotPerform as a first class attributes to all FHIR requests. This really should not be an extension.
column17: Recommend doNotPerform as first class on all base FHIR requests

column16: Recommend eliminating the notDone extension in favor of a 'not done' status as is done in the Procedure resource. This helps better consistency across FHIR.
column17: Eliminate notDone extension in favor of not done status

column16: Recommend eliminating reasonCancelled in favor of the more standard statusReason (defined in the FHIR patterns). reasonCancelled is only applicable to a single status - 'cancelled'. One may wish to provide reasons for other statuses.
column17: Eliminate reasonCancelled in favor of more standard statusReason

column16: FamilyMemberHistory should simply reference the Condition resource rather than creating an inline backbone element with the proposed extensions. Perhaps this should be a recommendation to the FHIR team.
The constraints on Medication.ingredient.item[x] look odd. Are they correct? They point to HTML pages.

It is pretty clear that there are a number of attributes pertaining to birth data. FHIR should consider making a backbone element called 'birth' or 'birthData' with children attributes for date, time, location, multipleBirth, etc… rather than using sibling elements sharing a common name prefix.
column17: Recommend a birthData element for base FHIR Patient

column16: In the table the displayed name of the QICore-DeviceRequest Profile is wrong. It should be QICore-DeviceRequest, instead if QICore-Device (which is in the previous row)
column17: In the table the displayed name of the QICore-DeviceRequest Profile is wrong.

column16: The expansion of the CQI to embrace QUICK, QI Core profiles and FHIR is a great initiative. The challenge will be to test and validate harmonizing the 3 reqources to deliver reliable informaiton exchange between QI efforts across the healthcare eco-system-care delivery, research and administrative. I did not see any conflicts in review of the tabs provided for this ballot so will leave it to others who may identify any that exist.
column17: How will QUICK, QI Core and FHIR be tested and validated?

column14: A code capturing the explanation of why the allergy or intolerance has been refuted. Should be specified only if the status is refuted.
column16: This extension seems to entered in error. If the intent was to create a coded extension descibing the patient's military status, the VA would like to be involved in specifying the terminoloygy
column17: Invalid extension definition re: military service

column16: I could not find an extension of data element "wasNotGiven" in the associated profile - http://hl7.org/fhir/us/qicore/2019SEP/StructureDefinition-qicore-immunization.html:
column17: Clarify how "was not given" is expressed in the qicore-immunization profile Is it using the "Immunization.status"?

column16: spelling, 2nd paragraph, 3rd line
QICore-Device is listed twice. The 2nd one should be for DeviceRequest.
